CardName: A Bright Center To The Universe (V1)
Lore: The intimidating power of the Empire was focused in the core systems, allowing the Emperor to ignore minor activities occurring on the Outer Rim.
Gametext: Deploy on table. Once per turn, if you control more battlegrounds than opponent, when you lose Force to a Force drain, may retrieve X Force (may not be canceled), where X = all bonuses to that Force drain.
Information: Article at DeckTech, November 1st, 2005\par Top 5 Damage-Controlling V-Cards (Dark Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par These cards (especially the LS version) were overshadowed in V9 by Entrenchment, but they are useful in their own right. These cards are powerful solutions to single site, mega drain decks that have plagued SWCCG throughout its lifetime. The biggest drawback is not getting cards lost from hand to the drain back into hand, so you lose hand advantage. If you lose from Reserve, you will get it right back into circulation, albeit at the bottom of your Reserve Deck. An enterprising player can use this expected retrieval to do some tracking. Some LS decks that are still popular, including AITC, offer many enhanced drains and being able to effectively ignore one of them is a great tool for the DS player.\par \par ARMAEDES' TAKE:\par This card almost made my list, actually. This is really good for those new Endor decks that can drain with three or four lightsabers at one location, turning a drain of 4-6 into a far more manageable drain of one or two. Also good for a Jedi Council Chambers drain deck that wants to hurt you for a big drain at a non-battleground using Jedi Lightsaber (V)s. A Bright Center To The Universe (V) makes those deck look silly. The only reason this didn't make my list is because of the qualifications of the card - you have to control more battlegrounds than the opponent. In certain situations, like the "drain at one location for a million" type of decks, this is easy to pull off, but against a deck that spreads and drains (i.e. QMC with Pucumir) this card loses a lot - if not all - of its potency.
IsPulled: Twi'lek Advisor\par We Must Accelerate Our Plans
Counterpart: The Planet That It's Farthest From (V9)

Gametext: Adds 3 to power of anything he pilots. May 'fly' (landspeed = 3). Permanent weapon is Projectile Grappling Hook (may target a character for free; draw destiny; target captured if destiny +1 > defense value). Immune to attrition < 3 (< 5 while with Jabba).
Information: Boba Fett personas are:\par \par Boba Fett\par Boba Fett (CC)\par Boba Fett (V6)\par Boba Fett (V8)\par [Boba Fett In Slave I]\par [Boba Fett In Slave I (V6)]\par Boba Fett With Blaster Rifle\par Boba Fett, Bounty Hunter\par Boba Fett, Bounty Hunter (V6)\par Boba Fett, Relentless Bounty Hunter (V6)\par -----\par SD-17 Homing Missile (V15) may deploy on Boba Fett.\par -----\par Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005\par Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Dark Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par When battling in SWCCG, it often is a huge advantage to start the fight, since you get the first action in the weapons segment. This can often mean the difference between victory and loss. Boba Fett changes all of that. He is the first character to key off of the "just" action of a battle being initiated. Some Interrupts in the past have done that, but never characters. This Boba is cool since he is an EPP w/o having a permanent weapon icon. Like Empy (V), this makes him eligible for a lot of cards we have mentioned before. The ability to easily remove a character from battle before your opponent has the ability to do anything is very potent. He essentially trumps all types of other weapons and text. Capturing is quite strong since it is not an "immediately lost" action that can be countered by cards like K'lor Slug and the like. From now on, the choice of Bobas will be between this version and BFBH.\par \par ARMAEDES' TAKE:\par I despise this Boba Fett persona. Not because he's bad, but because he's so friggin' good. I have played games against this guy where I had a big stack of mains on Fett with Binders. One of my favorite combinations is to add his Fett's Blaster Rifle (V) to him and then play Hidden Weapons and Defensive Fire (V). With the right destiny draws, you can very easily clear out 4 characters per battle (destiny +2 with his text, destiny +4 with Defensive Fire (V), destiny +2 with his rifle, then Hidden Weapons). Especially if you've got You Cannot Hide Forever out and Lando Calrissian (V) hiding somewhere, this Fett can definitely hold a site by himself. Mandalorian Mishap (V) makes him look stupid, but otherwise a very solid card.

One as a +2, one as a +6 plus an additional 2 during the weapons phase.1 draw for hidden weapons and + 4 for Bob's Rifle. But the kicker is opponent does not get a battle detiny by himself. Gametext: Plays on table. If opponent moves from a location you occupy during your turn, they lose 2 Force. At end of opponent's turn, if you control two battlegrounds (a site and system) and opponent deployed a card with ability and did not initiate a battle, you may retrieve 1 Force.
Information: Article at DeckTech, November 1st, 2005\par Top 5 Damage-Controlling V-Cards (Dark Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par Much ballyhooed when first released, these "offensive" Defensive Shields became a popular staple among most Shield lists. It's very easy to play since its initiation conditions are similar to another standby, Battle Order/Plan. These shields work to discourage cowardly play, like running away from battles on your turn (Watch out for Honor reducing this!) or not fighting you when they deploy to the table. Many decks have been built so that they can take full advantage of this gametext. [...]\par \par ARMAEDES' TAKE:\par Excellent choice, this was actually #6 on my list. It barely missed the cut because the second portion of the text requires that you control a site and a system to make it work, and hardcore battling decks rarely do this. The part of the card that makes the opponent lose Force can be good, but frankly if your opponent has a choice between taking a beating and losing a measley two cards (which, as you point out, is reduced by Honor Of The Jedi), they're going to lose the 2 no questions asked. In other words, those this is a card that should be played in every battling deck, it doesn't actually help your big battles happen because the opponent is still able to use their "escape" cards, they just have to lose a couple of Force to do so - which oftentimes is a fair trade.

Lore: Imperial stormtroopers deploy in 8-10 trooper squads. Reinforcements are typically held in reserve according to standard Imperial operating procedures.
Gametext: Once per game, if opponent has more cards with ability on table than you, draw destiny and retrieve up to that number of Imperials and/or Imperial starships (may take one retrieved card into hand). OR Cancel K'lor'slug.
Information: Quarren at a planet site makes Imperial Reinforcements (V2) a Used Interrupt.\par -----\par Article at DeckTech, November 1st, 2005\par Top 5 Damage-Controlling V-Cards (Dark Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par Somewhat limited in scope due to the fact that it only works on Imperials, Reinforcements (V) is still a solid card that can give a Dark deck some life back in the late game. It's really obnoxious when you keep losing your ability off the top of your deck and are unable to keep up with your opponent due to a weak-battling hand. Imperial Reinforcements (V) can correct this problem and breathe some life back into your deck by giving you some more ability to fight with. Other than the cards needing to be Imperial, there are no other stipulations, which means you can retrieve EPP Vader into hand if the opportunity arises. The ability to pull a powerful Imperial like EPP Vader out of the Lost Pile at any time is an incredible ability to have.\par \par SHEWSKI'S TAKE:\par \par Eh, yeah, it's pretty good but much like my comments on Merc Sunlet, I HATE having to rely on losing the game (at least being behind in terms of board control) to use a card. You don't mention canceling the Slug, which is very nice since there is so much Dark character removal. Getting up to 7 cards back is pretty strong, I just wish I could use it anytime.
IsPulled: Field Promotion (V5)
Cancels: K'lor'slug\par K'lor'slug (V2)

Information: Startable with Heading For The Medical Frigate.\par -----\par BG-J38 adds 2 to the destiny of each of your holograms and dejariks drawn for battle destiny or weapon destiny.\par -----\par BG-J38 (V8) makes dejariks destiny +2.\par -----\par Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005\par Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Light Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par One of my pet peeves, briefly touched upon under #1, is character removal. The Dark Side is rife with popular ways to get rid of your heroes such as Dr. Evazan, Dark Strike, and Choke Vader. K'lor Slug (and Molator for the DS) helps you avoid painful beatdowns due to sudden losses of power and destiny draws. While this is more like IMI in that it helps your battles hold their effectiveness, the second part of the text goes very well with immunity mains. Your mains can get out at their normal cost, which greatly speeds up the time it takes to get them into play by a turn or more.\par \par ARMAEDES' TAKE:\par Again, I find this less of an offensive aid than a defensive aid, and more of a battle-hindering card than anything else. The dark side's character removal is a big way dark wins battles, so in my opinion taking this away makes effective battling more challenging. I really like this card - I think it is a necessary component of the game - but I'm not sure I would classify it as a battling aid.

Gametext: While at opponent's Senate, Leia's game text may not be canceled and may lose 1 Force to place Leia and a character present out of play. During battle, may cancel game text of a leader of ability < 5 with Leia for remainder of turn.
Information: Leia Organa personas are:\par \par Boushh\par Daughter Of Skywalker\par Daughter Of Skywalker (V)\par Leia\par Leia (V)\par Leia, Optimistic Leader (V)\par Leia Organa\par Leia With Blaster Rifle\par Leia, Rebel Princess\par Princess Leia\par Princess Leia (V)\par Princess Leia, Lost Scion (V)\par Princess Leia Organa\par Princess Leia Organa (V)\par Princess Organa\par Prisoner 2187\par Senator Leia Organa (V)\par -----\par May not place Lord Sidious (V16) out of play.\par -----\par Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005\par Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Light Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par Leia is a revolutionary card. She is a very cheap destiny draw that allows for an early disruption of the Dark Side's setup. Though envisioned as an anti-Senate card, she has many other strong uses. Most used is probably her leader canceling game text, which can set up some beats of her own. She can take the teeth out of Jabba, Xizor, P-59, Fel, Igar, Ephant Mon, Veers, Thrawn, and Tarkin. This text always works as well. Typically, such a powerful card wouldn't be so cheap, but she has been an early thorn in my opponent's side for some time now. Usually my choice for a utility Leia, but Princess Leia (V) deserves consideration as well.\par \par ARMAEDES' TAKE:\par YES! Leia (V) is a fantastic battling card. Not only does she have strong gametext for battling herself, but she also takes a bite out of senate, which is a deck that makes effective battling by the light side more challenging. I would even put this Leia above EPP Leia for battling effectiveness. Great pick by Shewski!

Rules: Local Trouble Battle\par A Local Trouble battle is one where a battle has been initiated by a card titled Local Trouble. During a Local Trouble battle, any other characters, vehicles, or starships at the site that are not participating in the Local Trouble battle are inactive for the duration of the battle, with two specific exceptions:\par *If a character participating in a Local Trouble battle is on an open vehicle, that vehicle is not inactive.\par *Cards that become inactive because of a Local Trouble battle are considered to be on table for the purposes of objectives.\par Remember that these cards are inactive by rule, they are not considered excluded for any game-related purpose.

Rules: (AR 1.7.1, D-2)\par Characters, vehicles, and starships can be heroic (whether by their own game text or have it provided). Whenever a heroic card is targeted by a weapon, add 1 to the total weapon destiny. Also, in a battle where there's a heroic card, non-heroic cards cannot be targeted by weapons unless all heroic cards are hit, not participating in battle, or cannot be targeted by that weapon. \par For example, if light has a heroic character (Chewie) in a battle, then any dark side weapons that can target him can only be fired at him, but if they don't (such as targeting only a vehicle, or a non-Rebel character, or a Jedi, etc.) they wouldn't have to, if he was excluded from battle they wouldn't have to, if he left the table they wouldn't have to, if he was inside an enclosed vehicle (where he can't be targeted) they wouldn't have to, or if he was finally hit they wouldn't have to. Light would be able to target whomever they wanted because you can't target your own cards with weapons.

CardName: The Planet That It's Farthest From (V1)
Lore: The Rebellion operates freely in many Outer Rim territories, allowing them to ignore Imperial activities in the core systems.
Gametext: Deploy on table. Once per turn, if you control more battlegrounds than opponent, when you lose Force to a Force drain, may retrieve X Force (may not be canceled), where X = all bonuses to that Force drain.
Information: Article at DeckTech, November 1st, 2005\par Top 5 Damage-Controlling V-Cards (Dark Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par These cards (especially the LS version) were overshadowed in V9 by Entrenchment, but they are useful in their own right. These cards are powerful solutions to single site, mega drain decks that have plagued SWCCG throughout its lifetime. The biggest drawback is not getting cards lost from hand to the drain back into hand, so you lose hand advantage. If you lose from Reserve, you will get it right back into circulation, albeit at the bottom of your Reserve Deck. An enterprising player can use this expected retrieval to do some tracking. Some LS decks that are still popular, including AITC, offer many enhanced drains and being able to effectively ignore one of them is a great tool for the DS player.\par \par ARMAEDES' TAKE:\par This card almost made my list, actually. This is really good for those new Endor decks that can drain with three or four lightsabers at one location, turning a drain of 4-6 into a far more manageable drain of one or two. Also good for a Jedi Council Chambers drain deck that wants to hurt you for a big drain at a non-battleground using Jedi Lightsaber (V)s. A Bright Center To The Universe (V) makes those deck look silly. The only reason this didn't make my list is because of the qualifications of the card - you have to control more battlegrounds than the opponent. In certain situations, like the "drain at one location for a million" type of decks, this is easy to pull off, but against a deck that spreads and drains (i.e. QMC with Pucumir) this card loses a lot - if not all - of its potency.
IsPulled: It's Not My Fault (V)\par The Signal\par We Wish To Board At Once
Counterpart: A Bright Center To The Universe (V9)

Rules: (AR 1.7.1, D-2)\par Characters, vehicles, and starships can be heroic (whether by their own game text or have it provided). Whenever a heroic card is targeted by a weapon, add 1 to the total weapon destiny. Also, in a battle where there's a heroic card, non-heroic cards cannot be targeted by weapons unless all heroic cards are hit, not participating in battle, or cannot be targeted by that weapon. \par For example, if light has a heroic character (Chewie) in a battle, then any dark side weapons that can target him can only be fired at him, but if they don't (such as targeting only a vehicle, or a non-Rebel character, or a Jedi, etc.) they wouldn't have to, if he was excluded from battle they wouldn't have to, if he left the table they wouldn't have to, if he was inside an enclosed vehicle (where he can't be targeted) they wouldn't have to, or if he was finally hit they wouldn't have to. Light would be able to target whomever they wanted because you can't target your own cards with weapons.
IsCanceledBy: Heroic and immunity to attrition canceled by Coordinated Attack (V).

Information: Original card: <><><>Asteroid Field.\par -----\par Please check thread of Sonn (V13 General Rules Questions) here:\par http://www.swccgpc.com/forums/viewtopic.php?t=16053\par \par This is a space system, meaning it cannot be targeted as a planet. Thus it can be deployed using Hidden Base, but not by A New Secret Base.\par \par The blown away rules apply to this system: it cannot be converted once it is deployed. Remember that you cannot convert your own locations. The blown away rules state specific exceptions for systems that deploy blown away (the bottom left paragraph on page C-1): it retains its name, icons, and game text (thus you may still use Our Most Desperate Hour).\par \par The start of game rules state that if you are required to deploy a location, but are prevented from doing so solely because you cannot convert a location, you simply place your copy of the location out of play and continue (that is an exception to the normal rules). This means that if this is Light's starting location against SYCFA, Dark's objective would not be placed out of play; instead, they would just put their own copy of Alderaan out of play.\par \par This system has the Special Edition icon. Thus you cannot use it with It Is The Future You See (V).

Lore: At Cloud City, Luke came face to face with his own destiny. Looking into the abyss, he made his decision.
Gametext: Plays on table. Substituted battle destinies do not count against battle destiny limits. If all your battle destinies were canceled (and not redrawn) use 1 for your total battle destiny instead. Once per game, may play a Defensive Shield from under your Starting Effect.
Information: Please check thread of Sonn (V13 General Rules Questions) here:\par http://www.swccgpc.com/forums/viewtopic.php?t=16053\par \par "Limits," as stated in the current rulings thread, are when you're not allowed to do all that you would otherwise be permitted. So if you could draw 3 battle destiny but can only draw 2, this is a limit. If you could draw 2 battle destiny and can only draw 2, this is not a limit. In other words, these cards may only be used if you cannot draw all of the battle destinies you are otherwise entitled to, not to draw destinies you wouldn't normally get (for example, Luke Skywalker piloting Red 5 gets 1 battle destiny; he cannot use Chasm (V) and Darklighter Spin to draw 2).\par \par Normally you have no battle destiny if you do not successfully draw at least one battle destiny. As you can see, this provides an exception to the rule by providing you with a total battle destiny. Your battle destiny cannot be modified. However, your attrition of 1 may be modified (battle destiny determines attrition, but they are not the same thing, much like armor and defense value are not the same thing).
Pulls: A Defensive Shield from under Starting Effect.

Rules: (AR 1.7.1, D-2)\par Characters, vehicles, and starships can be heroic (whether by their own game text or have it provided). Whenever a heroic card is targeted by a weapon, add 1 to the total weapon destiny. Also, in a battle where there's a heroic card, non-heroic cards cannot be targeted by weapons unless all heroic cards are hit, not participating in battle, or cannot be targeted by that weapon. \par For example, if light has a heroic character (Chewie) in a battle, then any dark side weapons that can target him can only be fired at him, but if they don't (such as targeting only a vehicle, or a non-Rebel character, or a Jedi, etc.) they wouldn't have to, if he was excluded from battle they wouldn't have to, if he left the table they wouldn't have to, if he was inside an enclosed vehicle (where he can't be targeted) they wouldn't have to, or if he was finally hit they wouldn't have to. Light would be able to target whomever they wanted because you can't target your own cards with weapons.
IsCanceledBy: Heroic and immunity to attrition canceled by Precise Hit (V).

Lore: Wife of Owen Lars and guardian of Luke Skywalker. Quietly lobbied Owen to allow Luke to attend Academy. Maintains Lars' farm hydroponics labs.
Gametext: Once per turn, if present at a farm and a destiny was just drawn that is within 1 of the destiny of your 'crop,' may use 1 Force to place 'crop' in Used Pile. Whenever you play Beru Stew or Blue Milk, may draw top card from Reserve Deck.

Rules: Remember that Interrupts are played as soon as the initiation is complete but before it resolves. This means that after the Interrupt is played, the opponent has the first optional response; if the action hasn't yet been canceled, you may choose to draw a card. You cannot draw after you activate (as the time to choose optional responses has passed). \par Beru's game text allows you to effectively add or subtract one from the destiny of the 'crop' card on Lars Hydroponics Station for the purposes of removing it.

Information: Original card: Ralltiir Operations/In The Hands Of The Empire.
Rules: See the current ruling thread for information on how Local Trouble battles work. Moving from a Tatooine site means that the card began its movement at a Tatooine site, regardless of the destination.\par \par Local Trouble Battle\par A Local Trouble battle is one where a battle has been initiated by a card titled Local Trouble. During a Local Trouble battle, any other characters, vehicles, or starships at the site that are not participating in the Local Trouble battle are inactive for the duration of the battle, with two specific exceptions:\par *If a character participating in a Local Trouble battle is on an open vehicle, that vehicle is not inactive.\par *Cards that become inactive because of a Local Trouble battle are considered to be on table for the purposes of objectives.\par Remember that these cards are inactive by rule, they are not considered excluded for any game-related purpose.

Lore: Han did not take kindly to Jabba's posturing.
Gametext: USED: Use 1 Force to deploy an Effect that deploys for free on table (or your side of table) and is always (Immune to Alter) on table. STARTING: When drawing your starting hand, draw up to 12 cards instead of 8. Place this interrupt in Reserve Deck.
Pulls: Any (Immune to Alter) effect that deploys for free on table (or your side of table)
Rules: If you play this as a Starting Interrupt, you must draw at least 8 cards. You do not need to declare how many cards you will draw, you may continue to draw until you wish to stop (or have drawn 12 cards). The Used Interrupt function may not be used to deploy an Effect that lists any deploy cost in its game text (such as Beggar) or is conditionally immune to Alter (such as Well Guarded). You do not place cards in Used Pile if opponent has He Is Not Ready (V) or Our Most Desperate Hour (V) on table, unless you chose to draw exactly 8 cards total.
